zmeyRBxT5h8EzLiBYvKeGA.text: Definitely a fan - made the pick from Yelpers' reviews - and you all didn't steer us wrong.  First time hear - and not sure when the next time would be, so tried a few things:  the meatballs, the Biaggia pie and another special pie - red sauce, pancetta, red onions (I think) - all was delicious!    Like some other reviewers have mentioned, we had the opportunity to meet and chat with the owner - a very nice guy, who's really mastered the pizza art.  We ate outside - enjoying the nice cool evening air.  All in all a great experience!  Highly recommended.

oeZ0aJjHiCkmGnta5Z_iCQ.text: Ok, why is it that when it comes to writing REALLY good reviews, or REALLY bad reviews, I usually (not always) get it done straight away. But when it comes time to write the less than 5 star but more than 1 star review I procrastinate. In any case, here's my review of il Bosco, finally.   Where to begin, well, when you price your pizza in the same range as say Pizzeria Bianco, and you model your whole concept on them as well (more on this later), you better be phenomenal. But lamentably Il Bosco isn't phenomenal, theyre ok, the pizza is good, just not great. That said, the owner must have cajones the size of Texas to have priced his pizza in the same range as Chris Bianco's, or maybe its just his ego that's over inflated hence the over inflated price. As I've already said, its not bad, its just not $12-$15 per pizza great, the crust is good, but so delicate it cant handle a trip up the street a few blocks without completely collapsing into sogginess (I tried to take one home to my bro). I deduced that this must be the reason I saw 3 customers come in for take out and all of them had to wait as their pizza was cooked, after their arrival. They simply will not cook it until you are there to pick it up, which means you will always have a bit of a wait. We also had the meatballs al forno, which were not only small, but one of them was burnt, and I mean black spot burnt, but they served it to us anyway. Again, 2 of the 3 small meatballs were ok, they were good, but not, "hot damn I'm coming back here again soon" good, and the burnt one was not good at all of course. The caprese salad was probably the best thing we had there, but again, it was good, not great. The wine selection was decent, although I would say the reds are a better selection than the whites.   Now back to the afore mentioned similarities, like Biancos, Il Boscos menu features 2 salad choices, 2 small plate choices, and a variety of pizzas. Again just like Bianco's, they also offer house made mozzarella and bread, though the bread seems suspiciously dense, thick and un-Italian, not to mention nowhere in the vicinity of Bianco's quality either. This is where the menu similarities end though, Il Bosco offers 4 dessert options, but oddly, save for the the gelato, none of them are Italian, no tiramisu or cannoli here. Along with the gelato, a root beer float, brownies, and creme brulee are offered. What is a French dessert doing on the menu of a decidedly Italian restaurant (judging from the name Il Bosco which in Italian means woods or roughly forest)? Again, that suspiciously un-Italian vibe creeps up.  I bring my tome to an end by saying that a google search of Il Bosco filled in some of the blanks for me, and now I understand why my experience was what it was. Il Bosco is not Italian owned or operated, its actually the artistic retirement endeavor of a retired golf pro who isnt even close to being Italian (maybe THAT'S why the meatballs were so close in size to golf balls, lol). Well I'm old school, and for me, when it comes to better dining, you have to be Italian to make Italian food, and Ill pay more for the luxury if need be. That said, this place is ok if you're really hungry, in the area, and don't mind paying Pizzeria Bianco prices for pizza that is lesser in quality than Il Capo, which is right up the street.

fupu36AOqE0eoJw_-huvLQ.text: Awesome Pizza!  My favorite is the steak salad and bread, served with the olives.  Yum.  Perfect meal and I never feel heavy or overstuffed, just the right amount with great ambiance. A perfect cozy clean unassuming gem!  A mastery of sauce, bread, quality cheeses, and freshness.

rxg-A5IuEWD_GxFSEirzPg.text: Okay, okay, okay.  I endlessly daydream I am sitting at a quaint corner street in Naples, Italy eating al fresco with a beautiful fresh pie atop an iron table just a few inches larger than my plate.  The fragrant smell of fresh crushed tomatoes, warm mozzarella, earthy basil, and olive oily hand-rolled wood fired pizza crust wafting through my olfactory glands.  This dream is so often replayed in my mind that I must convince myself that I have actually never been outside of US territory (I know, it's a problem). While we all have our favorite food fixations, my particular obsession is, none other than, the pizza pie.  New York, Chicago, New Jersey, St. Louis, Detroit, New Haven, California, or even Naples.  I'll take it any way, all day, any where.  After visiting @ilboscoaz in Scottsdale, I was left pondering, "have I had better pizza than this?  I have had a lot of pizza!  Could this be........*GASP*........my favorite?  In Arizona?". It's like choosing our favorite of our pets and I assume parents with their children.  Can we have a favorite? (Yes, his name is Todd.  I have five animals because I am crazy.  He is my favorite.  He is a . I am a sucker for anything cute). To answer the question, I am still left without resolve, but what I can say is that I'll never forget the flavor and aroma of their Valentina . It simple: pepperoni, cheese, Calabrian chili crushed and mixed in with the sauce, drizzled with sweet, sweet . @ilboscoaz is tucked inside a back alley behind the shopping center at Scottsdale and Shea in Scottsdale, Arizona.  A seemingly unlikely place for the Universe's best pizza pie.  A hidden gem.  A place for us all to ponder the best pizza we've ever had; and maybe, just maybe, a little hole in the wall in Arizona has what we've all been searching for, the perfect slice.  Stop by @ilboscoaz in Scottsdale and decide for yourself.  We all need answers!  Check out my stories for more of our salivating experience.

0mSOmCQSZ2fVD7hl0pPH0Q.text: Years ago, my girlfriend and I stopped by Il Bosco after reading a lot of their positive Yelp reviews. The former owner was the man who brought our pizzas to the table. After delivering one, he brought out the second and ended up accidentally elbowing my soda, spilling it all over the first pizza, ruining it in the process. Looking annoyed, like it was my fault and not his, he quickly ordered another one in an extremely awkward moment with no apology given.  This was my first interaction with Bill Forrest, former golf pro and pizzaiolo of Il Bosco.  Despite this hiccup, we were both mutually impressed with the food and decided to go back, despite my reservations on the owner. During this second visit, which ran much more smoothly, I told my girlfriend I was going to ask Bill what he thought the best pizza (aside from his) was in Phoenix. Expecting a short, snarky answer, I was surprised that Bill actually stood and talked with us for 30 minutes about pizza. His favorites, his inspirations, what he likes and doesn't like about certain styles, as well as his opinion on Yelp reviews.  After this conversation, Bill (and his son) always remembered us. Bill would always come by and inquire to what new places we've visited lately and sought out recommendations from us. He consistently remembered our preferred orders, which always impressed me. Despite going to other restaurants much more frequently than Il Bosco, Bill never forgot about us.  When he passed away in 2018, something we found out about far after the fact, we were both saddened by the loss. Bill made spectacular pizza and created a warm and quirky little environment that reminded me of something you'd find in a place like Flagstaff. The place is now under new ownership, which from what I read, had a bit of controversy surrounding it. And in many ways, it's upsetting that his family is no longer attached to the restaurant. However, after a recent visit, I can confidently say that the food remains (mostly) unchanged.  Il Bosco pizzas are a combination of both traditional and unique creations, with the Mia breakfast-style pizza probably being the best of the bunch. Other favorites include the Biaggia for fig lovers and any red sauce style pizza. Ingredients are top notch, while crust remains crispy, light, and full of flavor.  Starters, such as their bread, meatballs, and fried ravioli are all solid options, while desserts seem to have changed a bit. I'd suggest bringing back the old lemon sorbetto, which was served directly out of an ice-cold lemon. But if not, the cookie a la mode is always a safe bet.  We didn't get a chance to speak to the new owner, as they became swamped once we arrived. But from what I overheard and observed, he seems to be very personable and inviting, so at least the customer service aspect of this place has remained intact. Allegedly, they are looking to open another location and expand. I'm sure they'll do well, as the place still seems to have a lot of regular customers.  Ultimately, I'm glad to see that Il Bosco still manages to deliver great pizza.   We miss you, Bill!

O3WJUXCY5Vx0-xPYxaOf9Q.text: These guys are killing it. This month, I enjoyed amazing pizza at Bianco, and had two fantastic dinners at Tratto, that were some of the best meals I have had in town. And then I walked into Bianco.   Now, the day before, I had been with a group from Univision and the most popular host of a Spanish language TV program in the world, and a judge on many cooking shows. When we walked in, the pizza chef at Bianco rushed out to meet him, and they went out of their way to make sure that everything that came to us was the best I have ever had there.  And the next night, I was asked by a close friend to return to IL Bosco. And, juxtaposed next to those four absolutely fabulous pies from Bianco...it was different, and to my palate, even more enjoyable.   The crust was a little more flavorful, and "yeastier". There was a little more tasty char, but not too much, crisper under the toppings, not overly bready on the edges, and it was just more complex than what we had the day before.   I don't want to say better....because they are very similar in style and both are fantastic, but I enjoyed the last pie more. And, while we were completely fawned over at Pizzeria Bianco because of my famous guest, the service at IL Bosco was even more attentive, and it was just us.  And the pie: In addition to the precision and complexity of the crust, Daniel the pizza chef, recommended something different in a pie he was trying with chorizo, braised onions, mushrooms, and an egg in the middle.  Not at all what I was salivating for walking in, but we dubbed the pie: "The greatest hangover dish ever created". The taste was incredible, and different, yet the comfort factor was out of this world with the egg-yolk mixing with the other ingredients. All accompanied by great, inexpensive red wine selections, that night the favorite was the Montepulciano. In a great pizza town, this is still the only place where I have never had a less than absolutely stellar pie, and working through the menu, I think I've now hit them all...keep innovating!

-DySovel8VujoZP6amzy7w.text: Possible Hidden Gem of Scottsdale?  Me and my friends came here recently for dinner on a whim. You almost wouldn't know it was there with the other businesses around. That being the case, I am very glad we found it.   We were sat right away and because of that we ordered right away because we knew what we wanted. Pizza, and lots of it. I'm pretty sure the ones that stuck to mind the most were the Gabriella(or maybe it was the Joanna?) and the special I ordered. One of them was more of a basic pepperoni pizza but man was it the best fancy pepperoni pizza I've had in awhile. I really enjoyed the sauce and the fact that it wasn't too greasy.   Now the pizza I got was one that had white sauce, Brocollini and Sausage. Those 3 things are definitely my jam when it comes to food but for some reason it wasn't quite up to par. The sauce and the pizza overall was still tasty but the Brocollini was a tad undercooked. Secondly if you notice in my picture below, there are no sausages. Profound Sadness. The only other gripe I had was their fancy sodas. I got the Cola but honestly I still was craving a regular ole Coke Cola. I honestly feel like they should use regular soda. It's cheaper and much tastier imo.  Ultimately I had an amazing experience though. Our waitress was nice and the owner was extremely friendly. He apologized and hooked us up with extra sausage on the side. When one of us needed ranch, he went all the way to a neighbor restaurant just to get some and then brought it over. Talk about customer service! Il Bosco would definitely be the pizza place I would go to if I lived here. It's probably one of the best pizza's places in the area that not everyone knows about.

jNYovimjGdV3znSPgRgkCg.text: Really great spot for lunch and dinner! We came in with a group of 6, for pizza and meatballs. Everything is made fresh including salad dressings from scratch and the pizza can easily be compared to most top pizza joints in Chicago or New York. It's definitely a hidden gem. They do not have a large menu, however if you are craving pizza - I would strongly recommend it! The owner even suggested an off the menu custom pizza and it was fantastic! Small place, get there early to avoid a wait!

Ktr_qva-alPzp_x7N5uZqQ.text: We discovered Il Bosco soon after it was opened many years ago by Bill,  a colorful a character, great golf instructor and damned good pizza maker.  Unfortunately, his boys took over the business, and it proceeded to take a huge dive.  His sons cared about your money, not the experience or the food.  You'll note the several recent 1-star reviews from their friends as they attempted to throw their last temper tantrum with bitter fake reviews.  Thankfully, the controlling interests sold the place to Jeff and his partner, and they have resurrected it with everything that matters - great pizza, salads, appetizers, wine and beer selections, and most importantly, engaged service.  Bill's staff stayed on, and it is readily apparent that they are in a much better place.  They're obviously happy and serving up some amazing food.    If you're looking a fun, comfortable and reasonably priced dining experience with indoor and outdoor options, this is as good as it gets!

1vuLUudT7kZGrEjydIRqbw.text: 1st time at the quaint old-town style restaurant, but we'll be back for sure! Tasty and original Italian pizza with a hint of wood flavor - perfect. Great beer on tap and wines. Interior decor is warm and informal with friendly service. It seems small-town nice, but in the heart of Scottsdale.

w3fs5D07EWCttmgnBv72zg.text: Bill would not approve. First time going since his passing. Pizza is not even close nor is the vibe. Won't be back. RIP

w1n0nv9j7BxKbh9Aw3jbKA.text: I have to agree with others that Il Bosco food is not what it used to be.  We have been dining at and LOVING Il Bosco since it originally opened.  The new owners claim nothing has changed, but it certainly has.  The pizza dough  is not like it was before -- the crust is chewy and flavorless.  The pizza toppings just don't taste the same.  Caesar salad is still delicious.  We have been a half dozen times under new ownership, but won't be returning.

qsSAlzIT44gggjvbNcXJhw.text: Flat out amazing!!!   The other night my wife were wandering aimlessly around looking for s place to eat.  All the sudden I remembered this pizza place. So we pull up, made sure they were open, we were seated by an amazing young waitress and had one of the best Pizza dinners of our life!   My wife had the Carmella pizza, gluten-free, which shot her to the moon! She was completely beside herself as to how amazing one: the gluten-free crust was and two: the overall taste and structure of the pizza! Myself  on the other hand, I chose the: Valentina pizza. The taste is something that I've never experienced before. It had the right amount of spice and flavor to it!Drop what you're doing this weekend, then race over to the Bosco. You will not be disappointed. Ever!

Pjy2e1ko_b73PkAIEOlYSQ.text: They now have spirits!!! Not like ghosts....like vodka and bourbon!! And limoncello!!! The pizza is out of this world!! Try the Biaggia...it will make anything wrong in your life all better!

237WT3nvyvfuusxozBJVuw.text: I feel late to the party discovering this place! Thank goodness for Yelp! or I'd never know about it!  We eat across the street at Guido's for years and never knew this place existed! So glad we found it!   This restaurant is very small (about the size of an ice cream shop). But the benefit is that it is very quiet and peaceful inside. The prices are fair and the pizza is very light.   I ordered the Adrianna pizza and it has to be the single best Margherita pizza I have ever had.   Unfortunately, there are no fountain machines here. Nor are there Coke or Pepsi products. They serve Boylan's sodas by the bottle. I like that it's different, but the soda beverage limitation negatively impacts my overall meal experience.  I imagine if I wanted a beer with my pizza, I'd be satisfied, but I'm not a beer or wine drinker. Perhaps I need to bring my own Coke with me next time?  My wife ordered the lunch special with a three topping pizza (pepperoni, mushroom and onions) and she absolutely loved it!  We will definitely be coming back here again. A shame its so hidden and finding a spot to park can be difficult when it's busy, but there is plenty of parking on the other side of Scottsdale Blvd, with a short walk. Totally worth it! Forget Pizzeria Bianco. While that pizza is good, this pizza is better on price, crowds and flavor!

SBpBEmgI7P19QoDik8XZ6A.text: I had been working next door to Il Bosco for the last 4 months and constantly smelling the deliciousness of pizza cooking. I would always tell myself, "one day when you get off work you need to go order a pizza!"  Well I finally went in and ordered my pizza. I've always loved the outdoor little patio seating, there's just something about it that says "comfy, inviting, relaxed"...and although I placed my order to -go, I do look forward to coming back to sit and dine on that patio with the beautiful weather coming.   Anyway, as I came into the pizza restaurant I was immediately greeted by Jeff the owner. I told him the story of how I had always wanted to try the food here and he talked with me for several minutes telling me about all the different choices of pizza on the menu. I settled on the "Carmela" which was sausage (I got the spicy), spinach, mushrooms, sauce, cheese.  It was prepared quickly and I enjoyed a nice glass of red wine while I waited. As soon as I got out to my car I couldn't wait till I got home, I had to have a slice. Seriously THE BEST pizza I've had in Arizona.... and I'm not just saying that. It's the real deal.   Growing up in Las Vegas there was a little pizza place that we would go to that I honestly have never found any place that has ever matched how good it was.... I have now found it.   Go... you won't be disappointed. I promise

zf1rwfaEQVh9AEy_oU6zIQ.text: I went to IL Bosco to celebrate a coworker's birthday. I've never been there before. It was right next to Handlebar J's. Cool place. Great location. And amazing food. Our starters were Caesar salad meatballs, and mozzarella with heirloom tomatoes. We could've just had that. The party had a selection of pizza... From traditional pepperoni to gluten free options. Some cool beers on tap (had Scottsdale Blonde and Ballast Point Sculpin). Smaller intimate restaurant with an active/engaged owner. Definitely impressed us! A great place to grab a bite before catching some country music next-door. We will be back!

SAwt0vjmPrrXvBUKU9G6hg.text: My wife and I were looking to do something a little different and just have a nice evening out together. We heard about a place called Il Bosco Pizza so we divided to check it out. I will warn it can be a little tricky to find but it is right next to Handlebar J in Scottsdale. It is a small place that reminded us of the little bodegas we visited while in Spain. Small, quaint, and authentic. We started with roasted vegetables  (beets) that were fantastic. They were roasted in the wood fired oven, which I think everything is cooked in. The beets were over the top of an incredibly creamy, what I believe was a mozzarella cheese, and simply seasoned. Loved them. We then chose a pizza made with a fig jam, prosciutto, mozzarella, and topped with arugula. Again fantastic. It was difficult to choose which pizza because they offered so many great combinations. Lots of top quality ingredients to choose from, gourmet cheeses, and and an authentic Italian crust - crispy from the brick oven, a little chewy (not doughy), and cooked perfectly.   I could go on but hopefully I've given you enough info to give this place a try. Great place for a date night!

ObsUvTXjgjJz5F0Bu84sGg.text: I had worked around the corner from this cute place for years, and for some reason everyone at my work raved about it... and I never went! Fast forward to a couple weeks ago, when I was craving a good pizza, but didn't want to make that infamous drive/wait in downtown Phx.   Me and my best gal showed up, and were promptly seated for dinner on a Thursday with little to no crowd around 6 PM (that quickly changed). We started with water and some delicious olives, and moved onto to the pizza... Let me tell you, if I could have one pizza for three meals a day, it would be the Valentina. Sweet/spicy-all in one. You NEED this in your life.   I woke up the next morning so sad we didn't order two pizzas and have leftovers honestly. So if I could change one thing, it would be that! Also, the owner is ridiculously sweet and stopped by the table. I will be back, and telling everyone about this place!!

5E9j8KkXfHgNEGJF7rR5wg.text: Great neighborhood find!  Pizza had a very crusty & good crust.  I had the one with the salami on top. The salami itself was ok (cut too think), but the rest of the pizza was great.  My boyfriend had the one with the sausage & it was good too.  The tomato mozzarella salad was just ok. I expected more after reading the reviews. The presentation of the salad was not so nice. It was drenched in balsamic dressing and a bit of pesto on top.

uyMFdhwfrWoyNlG5bWwnfw.text: (Lyrics - Kelis - Bossy)  Il Bosco It's a fresh bite to scream up my Yelp It switched up the beat to my heart That's right it brought imported cheese to the boulevard And that's right, it's the one who's firewood oven to start   Il Bosco It's a place y'all love to date It's a place that's raised the stakes I told Yelp Phoenix there's no debate I'm back with an appetite cause it's Bosco  Il Bosco Pizza is a locally own spot quaint and popping with some firewood cooked pizza; this place definitely has a lovely charm to it.    I came on a rainy evening so the place inside was packing!  I would say the inside seats a max of 35 people including the bar.  The open kitchen where you can see the firewood oven was an allure while chef craft his work.    We started with a bottle of wine plus some Fried Ravioli.  The ravioli came along with some sweet marinara sauce and had a decent soft doughiness to it.  Next we shot for the Caprese Salad; which was my favorite.  It came with Burrata cheese along with the traditional Mozzarella cheese, tomato, and balsamic.  Overall, one of my favorite bites of the night.  Fluffy burrata along with smooth and stringy mozzarella cheese ending with a sweet balsamic punch.    For our pizza we ordered their Biaggia & Carmela.  The Biaggia came with prociutto, fig jam, four cheese, and arugula.  Overall, a decent bite but I felt the arugula was over-powering.  The fig jam was light and I wish they would put more on it.  The Carmela came with tomato sauce, sausage, spinach, and caramelized onions.  The tomato sauce was a welcoming pairing with the saltiness of the sausage and sweet onions.  In the end, Il Bosco Pizza is a little sweet spot for some farm to table pizza.  Traditional Italian bites with some allure of the ambiance.  The firewood oven is awesome to watch, but not sure how well it fares during the summer months. - Enjoy!

0wHYDNltKnpRk1qIrWn7LA.text: Great food!! Fresh bread with perfect chewy crust! Their wood fire pizza was cooked to perfection with the crispy soft crust and perfectly charred bottom. We chose the Baggia pizza which had prosciutto, fig jam, four cheeses and arugula. Wow!! What a great combination! I love this style of pizza!! For dessert we had spumoni encased in dark chocolate. OMG!! So rich and delicious! Will certainly be back!!
